data.author: Adrian Camm

data.text: Set the whole bike up to be comfortable, then get a saddle that feels good when the bike is set up that way. Most of your weight should be on your feet most of the time. Grip position, width, and sweep or flare should be such that you can keep a reasonable amount of weight on your hands without pain in hands / wrists / elbows / shoulders / neck, so that you're not constantly leaning back and putting weight on the saddle instead of on your feet and hands.
data.author: Steve Williams

data.text: Padded shorts, good seat, training time
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: Make sure your saddle isn't too high. Your saddle can be even or lower than the handlebars if that makes your butt comfortable.
data.author: Kathy Wing

data.text: It‚Äôs all about butt fitness‚Ä¶.stronger the butt the more comfortable the ride. All the chamois, and special bike seats won‚Äôt help. Spend 8 weeks on the saddle 3-5 days a week for 30 min. You barely need a chamois at all.

data.text: Besides the blindingly obvious (quality padded shorts, and a saddle that works for you), make sure your bike is set up right and, most importantly, get some time in on the bike.

data.text: get off and walk around for a few minutes... or stand
data.author: Thom McAdams

data.text: Yea not a 'which saddle I should buy' solvable situation.. After 10 years of long day-rides in my 30's~40s I was fine on multi-month tours during my 40's>50's on an often mentioned leather saddle, and lined, but un padded bike shorts, as my base layer..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Ride out of the saddle when you can.
data.author: Chris Binch

data.text: Teach yourself to not put pressure on your bum, your weight can be on your legs and occasionally on your arms. You need to practice and condition your body for this.
data.author: Brian Alexander Langton

data.text: Don't do anything 8 hours a day. Not even 5 or 6. That is, not continuously. Breaks are your friend. Don't do too much the first few days. Build up progressively.

data.text: Get fitted to your bike have professional it's important.. get a good pair of riding bibs or shorts and seat time is the most important part.

data.text: I found a Brooks B17 saddle to be the answer. It was comfortable from the start. Have been riding on it for 5 years and wouldn't change it for any other saddle. I will admit though that not everyone fibds them comfortable.
data.author: Andy Shier

data.text: No secret - get right saddle, train and train and train! On very long endurance rides over 200km to 500km I apply loads of chamois cream on the padding - helps with the sweat and salt friction.
data.author: Andrew Stam

data.text: Lube up there butter cup..... kidding aside, bike fit, good chamois and lots of pre-ride miles will help. Nothing wrong with a little bit of Asos or Chamois Buttr creams .

data.text: I‚Äôve never used to much chamois butter, but I have used to little.

data.text: A good quality pair of padded shorts and Butt Butter
data.author: Dan Brill

data.text: 1) have experience riding for 6 consecutive days. 2) ride half your distance in the am, take a 2 hour break and then ride the second half. 3) Seriously, ride more. For a 24 hour race I trained at about 120 miles a week for three weeks. On race day my butt was on fire around mile 140. But it would have been on fire at mile 90 of my weekly mileage was lower. 4) ice and topical CBD salve are incredible anti-inflammatory products.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: Padded bike shorts help. Having a comfortable saddle makes a huge difference. Bought a new bike-the saddle was painful-replaced it with Terry bike seat-no more pain-and I ride long distances. It‚Äôs a good brand of bike seat.
data.author: Jane Schaffer

data.text: I found a piece of foam at the side of the road strapped it to the top of my saddle with gaffer tape, perfectly comfortable for the next few thousand miles. Nothing else I found makes much difference

data.text: Keep riding. Someday, you'll have no more feeling down there like meü§™ü§£

data.author: Steve Templeton

data.text: Every 10 minutes, raise up out of the seat for 10-15 seconds. This relieves pressure on the perineum. Also, stop every 1 to 1.5 hours for 10-20 minutes to recharge with fluids/snacks/stretching.
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: I used to do that too thinking that is a reasonable thing to relieve pressure but now I ride a recumbent and I just have no need to get out of the seat for anywhere up to 5 hours riding on a tour day . When I arrive I am still sitting in a comfortable chair and I get to watch diamond frame riders stop and walk around with sore seats and still think this is normal?
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Get padded shorts, try tredz as they are reasonably priced, endura do a range depending on how long u are going to be in the saddle. Just remember you get what u pay for. Chamois cream too and plenty of it x
data.author: Julie Hallam

data.text: Seat time is the only way to get better. There are two things holding you back, butt and brain. Fix them both and you‚Äôll be good to go.
data.author: Kent Clow

data.text: get a recumbent bike and you will find you have far more comfort with your speed. Up hills requires training just like any bike does , but but pain Nope . Too many cyclists put up with various pains as if this is a normal prerequisite,.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Fair enough , but are you gonna find me the spare ¬£1000/¬£3000 for one and where do you store it in a London terraced house ?
data.author: Davey Nellist

data.text: I've always wondered what recumbent cyclists make themselves feel better than everyone else. Too many cyclists put up with various pains? Maybe that's you. I got adjusted my bike.
data.author: Chris Hayworth

data.text: my experience is recumbents are tippy and unstable, and climbing very difficult. Happy to sell someone mine.
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: but the view and comfort are superior
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: When you ride a bike and have no problems with it you can say your bike is the one for you. One day your body may start objecting to sitting on 3 square inches of sit bones , and your hands may start to get numb from holding your body weight on the handlebars regardless of gloves and 5 different hand positions on drop bars. Your neck and shoulders start complaining about being held up and they did not complain before ? So you get a bike fit and a new saddle and different bars and your body still complains? Then maybe it is time to try the dark side and get a recumbent. No pain riding, comfort with speed , Visibility without holding your head up and hands on bars with maybe two positions but no pain to make them need a different position. People see you just as easily as you look into their beady eyes to make sure that they recognize you are there just as you do on a diamond frame bike. My seat is 15" wide and I sit in ,not on it. My feet are out front ,not dangling below me ,and I put out less wattage because of the aerodynamics. BTW I go up hills just as fast as I would on a diamond frame bike . Key word there is I. I do not race , I do not climb hills fast , I just get to the top as that is what counts ,not the seconds or minutes that the other guy may have to wait for me! However I do it in comfort.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: The first three weeks of riding my Rans Rocket dual 20" wheels was twitchy , unstable, and I thought a waste of money and then one day it all clicked together and the Rocket started to live up to it's name. I am currently building up another Rocket for touring except with disc brakes , and higher end components
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: I bought my Bacchetta Giro A 20 new for 3100 Canadian bucks to replace my Cafe which a couple months earlier was stolen as I watched. My latest buy is a 2005 Rans Rocket swb that has a 43" wheel base fits in the apartment easily and is fast and comfortable. I paid 250.00 for it and yes I am doing some modifications and when I am finished it will be 1350.00 total . The main problem with bents is they are not mass produced hence the price is higher and now that bent trikes are in style a lot of two wheeled bents are far cheaper than they were. I would buy used as the only difference between a diamond frame and the bent is the steering and the seat , everything else is either road or mountain bike components.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: sorry buddy I got that well and truly wrong.
data.author: Chris Hayworth

data.text: . Recumbents are unstable. expensive and ugly. They are also low and restrict your view making them dangerous in traffic. If a person does not have a physical disability that necessitates riding one of those ungainly monstrosities they are far better off learning to ride a standard bike. Other opinions may vary.
data.author: Greg Morath

data.text: Recumbents are unstable. Really ever watch a newbie climb onto a diamond frame bike for the first time ? expensive Top of the line recumbent for racing is far below what people put out for a custom carbon frame where I live. Obbsesion bikes north Vancouver BC road bike at entrance 10600.00 before upgrades that are available . My touring bent 3100.00 and ugly. Depends on which bent you are spitting at! They are also low and restrict your view making them dangerous in traffic. Obviously you have listened to someone else and not actually got on one for three weeks to get the feel and response as you would from riding a diamond frame bike, from beginner to 3 weeks . I get to hear all about how dangerous a bent is and how it can not be seen in traffic because they are so low? My VW Jetta is lower than the seat of my recumbent and as we all know Jetta's just can not be seen in traffic? There are very few racing recumbents that are ridden to work as racing and low to the ground in their particular case is what they are built for . My touring recumbent is high enough for me to look into the eyes of drivers of cars and trucks If a person does not have a physical disability that necessitates riding one of those ungainly monstrosities they are far better off learning to ride a standard bike. I have nerve damage in both hands that prevent me from holding my body weight on my hands as all diamond frame bikes have as a normal way of holding the handle bars. After riding my recumbent with it's 15" wide full mesh seat that I sit in , not on , a diamond frame bike saddle no matter how custom you want it to be is like sitting on a fence post! I no longer have to hold my head up as I am seated in a comfortable chair , so no neck shoulder pains over distance. My feet are out front not dragging in the wind so my wattage output for speed is less. One day when you are old enough to get past peer pressure and fables about recumbents you will find that there is indeed a great deal of difference , positive difference. BTW pedestrians get hit by cars and trucks , so do bicyclists , so do Cows , so if the driver of the car or truck is not paying attention you can dress yourself up like Barney the dinosaur in bright purple or Big Bird in Yellow ,and it will not make a bit of difference!
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: . I am happy that you found a solution to the nerve disability in your hands, so recumbents may be right for you. The fact remains however that they are expensive, ungainly, complicated and are more dangerous in traffic due to thier low stature. On my bike I can see over traffic and traffic can also see me. Recumbents are also obviously more expensive compared to other bikes. I can walk in a bike shop and find many high quality bikes for less than $1000, can the same be said for recumbents? Also, the trike recumbents are a huge hassle to transport by motor vehicle. There are many more reasons that standard bikes are far superior for the general public than recumbents. Low and slow is not for everybody, and I fly past recumbents on a daily basis as I sit up high and enjoy the beautiful expansive views!
data.author: Greg Morath

data.text: The fact remains however that they are expensive, ungainly, complicated and are more dangerous in traffic due to thier low stature. On my bike I can see over traffic and traffic can also see me. Just what recumbent have you ridden in traffic to make the assumption they are low and can not be seen? I ride in Vancouver BC with no problems being seen or seeing . complicated ? Steering and seat is different ,and every other part is either road or mountain bike components so yes real complicated! Expensive depends on what you want as my latest recumbent is a 2005 Rans Rocket that I picked up for 250.00 fully functional . Why buy new if old is good enough. My top of the line touring recumbent Bacchetta Giro A 20 is currently 2300 US. Go find a top of the line touring bike and you will see what you can pay . So do tell us what recumbents you have taken out for three weeks to properly access their specific attributes ? BTW it took me over a year to do a track stand on a diamond frame bike and over a year to do really slow riding behind great grandmothers with a cane on my recumbent. Nothing happens in a couple days riding anything.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: . Well, I have certainly never passed a recumbent that was not significantly lower that me. My friend calls those low slung trike recumbents "ground dwelling clown cars", but I think that is a bit insensitive.
data.author: Greg Morath

data.text: Trikes are a whole different species than the recumbent bike and having owned one I never took it anywhere near traffic. My touring two wheeled recumbent has me sitting at 24" off the ground which puts me in good view of traffic being seen ,or seeing. My Rocket with dual 20" wheels still has me seated at 23" off the ground which is far nicer than a trike where you are seated 4-8" off the ground . Although lots of people own them I see more trikes on trails away from the roads traveled by cars , which in my opinion is a good place for them. Ground dwelling low lifes , some definitely are .
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.author: Deb Thomas

data.text: My big problem was chafing. Turns out a gel saddle chafes more due to the squishiness. It grabs your clothes and causes a lot of friction down there. I switched to the English leather saddle often mentioned here and the chafing disappeared on the first ride. As it broke in it just more and more comfortable. There's a reason why equestrians still use leather tack. No more monkey butt!

Of course, if you have the money to throw at it. A good bikefit with a guy equipped with pressure mapping equipment will be able to get there faster.

data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: I stop riding every winter and have had this issue many springs. It takes very little to work your way up. Do as little as 10 minute rides twice a day for a week. Make sure you quit riding BEFORE your butt gets sore. If you can take 2 weeks and some longer rides in week 2 even better always quitting before you get too sore. As mentioned by several people, a bike fit is a good idea. A common issue is weight distribution between butt and shoulders. Make sure you're not sitting too upright.
data.author: Harold Smith

data.text: Depends a lot on your riding style and the angle you sit at. For my endurance road bike I got a Brooks c15. I use good quality bib shorts and apply a little chamois butter to the junction between leg and crotch. Chunk up the day into 2h chunks with a break for coffee or lunch in between. I‚Äôd also advocate taking less weight, going faster and therefore spending less time in the saddle.
data.author: James Kitching

data.text: Notice how much we compensate for saddle pain as if it is normal? Chamois butter , padded shorts , don't sit upright, break up the ride so we don't sit on 3 square inches of sit bones and get sore? as you age it ain't gonna get better, so maybe going to the dark side and a comfortable recumbent is a far better choice than putting up with any pains? I really should have switched sooner .
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: good luck if it works for you. I like to do steep and hilly rides (I have to do in the part of the UK where I live). I am happy enough doing 80miles a day for a couple of weeks on my bike and by the end of that I am accustomed to it and could go on if time allows.
data.author: James Kitching

data.text: I never see recumbents where I ride. I ride a lot of dirt trails in the mountains. So it all boils down to the type of riding a person is doing. If you're on fairly level paved or hard pack, then maybe a recumbent will be just fine. Another factor is the amount of maintenance. Lots of long chain, sprockets etc., on many recumbents. Get a good bike fit, find a proper saddle for the type of posture you plan on being in while riding aggressive vs more upright and make sure you have your seat bone measurements when you start your saddle search. It takes a bit of saddle time before you can toughen up your butt. Ride an hour or so each day for 4-5 days, then increase your ride time a bit. Get off the bike and stretch, walk around and enjoy where you are at least every hour or so. Pretty soon, you'll be riding 4-6 hours over the course of a day without issue. Take breaks!
data.author: Norm Snyder

data.text: It takes a bit of saddle time before you can toughen up your butt. Eventually you may find that your body just ignores everything you have tried to make it comfortable and you may need to change style of conveyance! Another factor is the amount of maintenance. Lots of long chain, sprockets etc., on many recumbents. IIRC my recumbent has 2.5 lengths of chain that travels around the triple chainwheels, over one idler wheel and the 9 speed cassette in the back , and my mountain bike has a single length of chain that travels around the triple chain wheels and then around the 8 speed cassette in the back. So not really complicated . Look on the bright side the recumbent chain gets me all 27 gears as cross chaining does not exist, and lasts 2.5 times as long as the mountain bike chain does.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Padded short and Chamois cream.
data.author: Andy Southam

data.text: Padded shorts, correct fitting seat to your sit bones and most of all a few weeks of rides to condition your butt to the job. Then just endure the pain. That‚Äôs about all you can do ü§£
data.author: Andrew Neal

data.text: Tide as much as possible as time will allow.
data.author: Jack Farris

data.text: Notice all the comments are dealing with pain but not dealing with the source? Get a better bike as in a recumbent as the only thing holding you back is peer pressure and conformity. I sit in my full mesh seat and it is 15" wide . I am comfortable and on 4-5 hour rides there is no need for chamois butter, padded shorts, getting up off the seat to relieve pressure, or even a stop to walk around. My feet are out front, not in the wind creating drag , I don't hold my head up to see where I am going , my hands do not need constant adjusting as there is no body weight on them , I am seen by drivers of cars and trucks as I am looking into their eyes as well. I really should have gotten off the diamond frame sooner but 37 years of riding gave me some nasty reminders of sore hands , sore butt, sore neck , and that all went away when I finally bought my first recumbent. SWB, LWB, Mid wheel base , lots more variety and far different attributes to speed and comfort that a diamond frame will never give you.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Not a dealer just someone pointing out an alternative to riding a diamond frame with 37 years of experience before making the move to pain free riding. Where do you put your diamond frame bike ? I have a mountain bike hanging in the storage area and the Rans Rocket hangs in the same place and takes up the same amount of room. If I take either of them into the apartment they take up the same space. The mountain bike is 68"long Giro A20 recumbent is 72" long and my Rocket swb is 60"
